channel.title: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file
channel.description:
[code] String = "Hello" File = open("Hello.txt", "r")
if String in File: print "String in file" else: print "String not in file" [/code]
That opens 'file' and checks if string is contained inside, enjoy

item.title: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

[quote=“philodespotos, post:6, topic:4501”]The filename was named ‘meh’. Check the top of my paste.

I have no idea what that paste is supposed to be. How can you put a literal “======” into the python interpreter?[/quote]

The “=====” was from when IDLE restarted my code.

Read full topic

item.title: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

s = "goes here"
fd = open("meh", "r")
if s in fd:
  print "yeppers."
else:
  print "nopers."

First of all, I’m pretty sure you need to include the extension “.txt” at the end of your name, And it works fine for me

Change your “meh”

("meh.txt", "r")

I put this in the “New Wndow” in lamest terms

String = "Hello"
File = open("Hello.txt", "r")

if String in File:
    print "String in file"
else:
    print "String not in file"
>>> ================================ RESTART
================================
>>> 
String in file
>>>

Read full topic
item.source: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file

item.title: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file
item.dc:creator: @philodespotos philodespotos
item.description:
@philodespotos wrote:

What implementation are you using? That should not work.

$ cat >meh
any
random text
goes here
$ python
Python 2.4.3 (#1, May 18 2006, 07:40:45) 
[GCC 3.3.3 (cygwin special)] on cygwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> s = "goes here"
>>> fd = open("meh", "r")
>>> if s in fd:
...   print "yeppers."
... else:
...   print "nopers."
... 
nopers.
>>> # to illustrate why this can't work:                  
... print fd
<open file 'meh', mode 'r' at 0x49d728>
>>> # starting over to ensure no funny business:
>>> s = "goes here"
>>> fd = open("meh", "r")
>>> if s in fd.read():
...   print "yes."
... 
yes.

Particularly, note the result of “print fd”.

Read full topic
item.source: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file

item.title: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:
@thiefmn6092 wrote:

[quote=“philodespotos, post:2, topic:4501”]open() returns an fd. You need to call read() on that object in order to fetch the actual text.

if searchString in open(filename, "r").read(): print "yeppers." [/quote]

Nope,

[code]

String = “Hello”
File = open(“Hello.txt”, “r”)

if String in File:
print “String in file”
else:
print “String not in file”

[/code] works perfectly

Read full topic
item.source: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file

item.title: [Python] Finding a String/Integer in a text file
item.dc:creator: @philodespotos philodespotos
item.description:
@philodespotos wrote:

open() returns an fd. You need to call read() on that object in order to fetch the actual text.

if searchString in open(filename, "r").read():
    print "yeppers."
